course.subject: CORE
course.name: Exploration of Chinese Calligraphy
course.description: Chinese Calligraphy is one of the most unique traditional art forms in Asia. This course will develop students' appreciation of various types of Chinese Calligraphy. The course provides practical writing workshops which can encourage students’ interest and experience the progress; deepen students’ understanding basic calligraphic skill and generate visual creativity. It prepares students having a better overview of Chinese culture.
course.prerequisites: a passing letter grade in CORE 1401 OR CORE 1402 OR CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1002 (prior to 2022-23)

reviews.author: catslave123
reviews.title: Don't choose this course, worse course ever in ust!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Check out what others said.
He required us to buy papers by ourselves. You only start to write Chinese Calligraphy after add-drop. Please drop it as soon as possible. The course required you to master Chinese calligraphy in 3 weeks after semester start. You need to finish writing the Chinese poem in an hour, which is nearly impossible for beginners but he won't make any arrangements and only ask you to practise more.
The course is extremely unreasonable. You have hours of lesson listening to him talking about the History of Chinese calligraphy. But all your grade depends on how well you write while you only have 30 minutes actually writing Chinese Calligraphy in the tutorials.
reviews.comment_teaching: Worst teacher ever... He only rate the student based on Chinese Calligraphy skills. He himself can't even write pretty calligraphy, we have asked him to demonstrated once, it leaves us speechless. He is not an expert in chinese calligraphy, not even in chinese history or literature. He switches between English, Cantonese and Putonghua in the lesson but his English and Putonghua are poor. We tried so hard to write Calligraphy but the ink keep splitting on the paper. We asked him and he said it was a skill issue. But later when we're doing the project and we do some research and found out that the problem is the paper. The paper he asked us to buy is for Chinese painting so the ink can spread so easily. The paper for Chinese Calligraphy should be another type of paper. You also need to hear him judging your piece while him being such a non-professional.
reviews.comment_grading: It's a disaster really. I know nothing about Chinese Calligraphy and got a D. I put many hours into it but apparently there's only small amount of students and some have at least learn Chinese calligraphy for 3-5 years. The grading should be cumulative. If you are not a master of Chinese Calligraphy, just don't reg this course. I never got C range or D in any other courses.
reviews.comment_workload: The teacher asked us how many hours we practise a week. At least 4 to 5 hours sound good to him. I thought this is a beginner friendly course for anyone that wants to pick up a new hobby or experience. Even you try to practise every day for few hours, if he still think you write poorly, he won't appreciate any effort and ask you to do more practices. The workload is severely heavy. There's also a project that require you to put anything related to Chinese Calligraphy inside that A4 art book.

reviews.author: Lato
reviews.title: Beginners DON'T choose
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture:
Calligraphy History
Masterpiece Study
Standard script 楷書 & Cursive script 行書 (mainly)

Tutorial:
Practical writing
(see others)

You have to buy materials yourself, around $300, because the 宣紙 cost around $180 (a lot), others are not expensive.  開紙刀 is mentioned but never used, no need to buy in fact
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not a good experience at all

The instructor was rude when he was answering some questions, feel like he was impatient

This course supposed to be taught in English except the Chinese characters and some terms were pronounced in Chinese, but the instructor always speak in Cantonese, and then English , so the lessons are alternately Cantonese and English. If you can't understand Cantonese, don't choose this course

You need to practice writing in the 1hr tutorials, the instructor showed some masterpieces on the screen and asked you to follow, no demonstration or instruction, he just walk around to observe students' works, nothing difference to practicing at home

Boring teaching at all, don't choose as cc course
reviews.comment_grading:
1. 10% Attendance
2. 30% Mid-term project  (Produce a piece of standard script 楷書 in class)
3. 40% Final Presentation (Create a set of standard script 楷書 or cursive script 行書 calligraphy artwork in large and small sizes. (In class & Homework))
4. 20% Learning portfolio (A journal that reflect one’s own learning progress, observations, and ideas
during the semester, written in hard copy and then scan it and upload in soft copy)

NO  marks were released so you cannot know his grading criteria

The project accounted for majority of the grading, if you know nothing about Chinese calligraphy, just don't choose this course because there were many students with rich experience in calligraphy, you won't write as pretty as them in a few months
reviews.comment_workload:
Depends on your experience

For beginners, you may have to spend many time to practice writing

Remember to write the portfolio every week, otherwise you may forget the content taught before

reviews.author: MYW_8210
reviews.title: You better be a Chinese caligraphy master, else you will get a C range or lower
reviews.comment_content:
Don't want to copy again.
Basically practice standard script 楷書 and semi-cursive script 行書. Visit museum. Instructor will advise you to buy his suggested material (around $300), You can bring your own brush or paper, won't make any difference though.
Don't expect that you can learn how to write Chinese caligraphy in this course. This course is basically equivalent to practicing by yourself at home.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The worst instructor I've seen in my life. His teaching is a piece of shit. Lecture is 2 hours, followed by 1 hour tutorial. Lecture is mainly about development of caligraphy, and about masterpieces. Instructor demonstrates a boring lesson perfectly.

He always tell the students to not hesitate to ask questions, but he obviously feels annoyed when people really do so, and ask other students to answer your stupid questions, etc.

I am a local student, but I can't understand what he is saying and what's his main idea. He always switched between English to Cantonese, causing an inconsistency for what he's saying. I really wonder if the non-locals can understand his speech. Sometimes he tried to speak Mandarin, but he needs students to guide him lol.

But still, the attendance are high, because it is counted towards the grading. I still get a C even though attended every lessons.

In the tutorial, you will bring your own brush and practice writing. Instructor won't 'teach' you, he would just put the masterpiece on canvas and tell you to imitate the writings.
I've never given a E on any course, he managed to do so, good job!
reviews.comment_grading:
10% attendance
30% mid term project
40% final project
20% learning portfolio (sketchbook+digital version)

But these information is not important, because you won't know any of your marks. So he can give any grade he wants lol.

I get a C finally. I appreciate his generosity for not giving me D or F.

If you try this course because you have experience in primary school, I promise you can get similar grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Basically the workload is from the learning portfolio.
Another workload is to waste 3 hours per week to listen to his boring lecture for attendance.
PS: After you've finished your portfolio, he will tell you that you don't need to submit the sketchbook version, only need to submit the digital version on canvas.

Course Description
Chinese Calligraphy is one of the most unique traditional art form in Asia. This course will develop students'
appreciation of various types of Chinese Calligraphy.
The course provides practical writing workshops which can encourage students’ interest and experience the
progress; deepen students’ understanding basic calligraphic skill and generate visual creativity. It prepares
students having better overviews of Chinese culture
Intended Learning Outcomes
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be able to:
1. Understand a major Chinese art form
2. Apply knowledge and technical skills of brush work and styles of Chinese calligraphy
3. Analyze the development of calligraphy through Chinese art history and the influences in the society nowadays
4. Create Chinese calligraphy artwork in a few styles and varies sizes
